utterances: (Soundbite of laughter)
I saw parents warming up in the parking lot, stretching.
Yeah.
Kind of a combative environment there, you know.
I don't know.
It's crazy.
I heard one father say: You even look down the toy aisle, boy, I'll knock your head clear off your shoulders.
I said ha, ha, I'm not in your family, sir.
You can't talk to me like that.
So, uh, yeah.
But it's interesting.
I did all my Christmas shopping in Baghdad this year.
Yeah.
I did that.
I figured I'd get it out of the way while I was overseas doing my tours.

And it's great because I wanted to do something that was, you know, I could buy something that's real expensive in Baghdad and bring it home, and it would seem really expensive to everybody back here.
So I just bought them gasoline, and yeah.
(Soundbite of laughter)
(Soundbite of applause)
Yeah, wow.
An applause break from 30 people.
That's cool.
But yeah, it's going to be an interesting year, giving gasoline as a Christmas gifts, because my dad smokes.
So that's going to be fun.
So yeah, it's cool.
But how about a hand for the men and women that are overseas that aren't with us today?
That's nice, huh?
Good people.
(Soundbite of applause)
I do - I've got to keep this short.

I do have to say I was very surprised in my tours of Iraq and Afghanistan, to find out that the United States military - the leaders of the coalition forces, the most feared military on the planet - drinks out of juicy boxes.
Man, what the hell?
I was so freaked out by this.
Go into the mess hall, and I was like what is this?
I couldn't believe it.
And so another condemnation of how Gadhafi and his regime are targeting Misrata.
And Lourdes, help us understand what's going on in the far west of the country, where fighting is also going on.
Thank you very much.
It's great to have a chance to talk with you today.
Juicy boxes?
You're not supposed to be drinking out of kids' juicy-box, box things.
You're supposed to be, like, punching each other in the face in the motor pool and eating nails.
But I was so mad.
I told them all, I said you take one of these juicy boxes, and you go back to your hooch or your tent - whatever you call it.
You take one, and you go and you stand in front of a mirror, and you try and say something that makes you look badass with a juicy box in your hand.
You cannot do it.
Oh, I'm gonna just kill that guy, hmmmm.
Just it's ridiculous.
Oh, man.
Well, okay, well you know, I was in the military, I make a little light of the military.
But I was in Charlie Company, Fifth Engineers, Fort Leonard Wood, Missouri.
Anybody?
Going once.
Going…
(Soundbite of audience member)
Oh nice, there are some people there.
I thought they went out of business after I left.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Yeah.
But I - military has changed, folks.
I'll tell you, I go over, I do shows overseas, and I'll tell you it's just night and day from when I was in.
I stand in front of these crowds, I look out, and I'm like wow, it's so bizarrely different to me.
Like, the biggest difference I can think of is that when I was in the military, man, women weren't allowed to have moustaches.
It's just, you know…
(Soundbite of laughter)
It's new, it's new for me.
It's different.
It's getting used to it.
I saw one girl in Fallujah with a full-on Fu Man Chu.
I thought wow, she must be special forces to get to keep that one.
So - ladies, don't get upset.
I've seen some man-boobs overseas, and I thought dude, wow, you need to go the PX and pick up and pick up a bra.
So thank you all.
Tom Irwin.
Support the troops.
Thank you.
(Soundbite of applause)
That's Tom Irwin, stand-up comedian who performs for front-line troops in Iraq and Afghanistan with the group Comics On Duty, and this is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
We're at Fort Dix, New Jersey today.
Tom, how did you get involved in the idea of performing at the front lines?
Well, Robert, I'm a vet myself.
So when war started up, you know, I just thought, you know, what could be - you know, it can't be any worse than most of the clubs I play in the Midwest…
(Soundbite of laughter)
So I just thought, like, let's take it to Baghdad, folks.

So I called up, I found out there is an organization that you can go through, called Comics On Duty, out of Michigan, and I sent in my press kit and everything and said I want to go overseas and, you know, do shows for the troops.
And I didn't hear from them for about a year.
And then they called me one day and said we'd like you to go to Iraq, but you've got to tell us if you can go right now.
So I said sure, of course, which sounds brave, but it wasn't.
I was scared to death as soon as I hung up.
But you know, you just figure it out, and tell your parents and freak them out, and then you just go over.
So you know…
And you go over, and you do the same stuff that you do in Michigan or Los Angeles, or…?
Well, it depends.
I mean, being a vet myself, it's fun for me because I get - I kind of have an inside track as to the daily workings of being in the military.
So you know - and I kind of, you know, it was kind of an easy transition for me to get out of the service and become a comic because the services didn't really want to keep me.
I didn't get a re-enlistment meeting.
They just said why don't you move on.
We're kind of - you know, you go your way, we'll go ours.
And so it was kind of a mutual agreement.
Did they suggest stand-up comedy to you as a second career?
No, but they definitely suggested that I get out of the military, so you know.
But I have a great admiration for the military, just, you know, from afar.
So, no.

I'd like you to tell the story that you relate in the DVD, which illustrates the gratitude you encounter and you experience from guys who go -and women - who go to hear your shows when you're in Iraq.
Yeah.
Well, it was - that story is based on the first time we were doing a show right on the border of Iraq and Afghanistan - or excuse me, Iraq and Kuwait.
And we did our first show, and we did our first what they call a meet and greet.

And about 300 soldiers waited in line to meet us, to say thank you to us - which really seems like a very odd situation to be in, when you're standing in front of a group of people who, first of all, look like everybody that you know as they walk by you.
But they are in this situation, in what I feel is a sacrificial place, to go and do something great for all of us back here, and they're the ones thanking us.
It was a real kind of a role-reversal that, emotionally, was a pretty heavy thing to deal with.
One soldier stood up and gave you a CD.
Yeah.
Do you remember what CDs were everybody?
Stand up and gave you a CD.
Wow, remember what CDs were.
Yeah, he gave me a CD that was by a singer named Tom Irwin.
And it was funny because he waited - he saw my poster in the mess hall two weeks prior to our visit - and he waited in line, and he brought it to me and give it to me and said thank you.
He said thank you very much for coming and doing what you do.
And it was very profound because, to have him actually give me something in kind of - it was premeditated.
He waited, and he said this guy has the same name as you, so I thought that you would, you know, want this CD.
It's just incredible, just, you know - the military has - you know, everyone we meet after the shows, it's the best part of going.
To actually meet and to talk with the people who are over there.
Yes.
Have you determined, after all these shows, that there are some kinds of jokes that positively do not work when you are on the road in Iraq?
Oh gosh - half my set?
So you know, I don't know.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Have you heard from the math teachers saying other things like, keep the studies going, and give us more of this?
Right now it is--we have a two-story home right off of Lake Pontchartrain, and it is to the roof line with water.
So...
I mean, it ebbs and flows.

I mean - the hard part about that, honestly, is that you could be in front of a bunch of guys or women, men and women, that they might have just lost, you know, six or seven guys that day, prior to your visit, or that morning they might have lost somebody.
So the thing is, is that the situation of where you're - who you're performing in front of, you're not even quite sure what variables they were exposed to before you came out.
But you know, I have to say that we're pretty welcomed there.
You know, I mean, it's a break that people look forward to.
I mean, I spent Thanksgiving in Fallujah.
We did two shows with the Marines.
Which is great, being an ex-Army guy telling a room full of Marines that you were in the Army, because you might as well tell them you have a flair for interior design.
You know, they couldn't care less, you know?
(Soundbite of laughter)
And you know, I always get that out of the way first.

So they were just really - you know, but to see the people come out in their, what they call full battle rattle, which is your helmet, your flak vest, anything that you carry, dusty, dirty weapons under their seats.
You know, come out of the field, guys.
We're pulling you out of the city.
Here's a comedy show, and then get up and get back.
You know, it's a very odd dynamic.
Very, very unusual booking, I should think.
Yes.
